text:
Thank you, Abby and Ryan, for
the wonderful introduction.

Hello and welcome to the
members of the Class of 2021.

Welcome to parents,
partners, friends,

and all of our loved ones who
supported us on this journey

to and during our time at
the Harvard Business School.

638 days ago, we all
sat in Klarman together

and heard that
timeline laid out.
A question hung in the air.

What would we do
with those days?

Between then and
now, how were we

to become leaders who make
a difference in the world?

I know that phrase immediately
elicited eye rolls.

I mean, how many times
have we heard it?

From our acceptance
letters and start,

to every email
we've ever received,

including many you got from
me, to the banners currently

hanging on campus,
that phrase is

supposed to inform us
why we're all here.

Occasionally, we
question whether we

should specify that we'd like
it to be a positive difference.

It's important to set
clear expectations.

But often, we repeat
it absent-mindedly,

when we need a feel good way
to wrap up some HBS-centric
communication.

But what is a leader, and
what makes a difference?

500 cases later, and there is
still no definitive answer.

In LEAD, we learned
that leaders probably

don't look like Eric
Peterson, and definitely
not like Rob Parsons.

We asked if being
first, different, unique

was enough to be a leader,
and whether to focus

on a bold stroke
or a long march.

We nearly always see
these protagonists

at a pivotal moment,
about to make

a choice that will change
a career, a company,
or a country.

And then, we decide, are
they a leader or not?

The problem with
this approach is

that leaders are not often
made in these pivotal moments.

True leadership,
it's the compilation
of 1,000 little decisions.

Leaders cannot be identified
through titles or lists
of responsibilities.

We all know at least one
person with an impressive title

that provides only the
illusion of competency.

So if the title of president,
mayor, or managing director,

or spearheading an
NPV positive project

doesn't make me a
leader, what does?

I remember the Shad
exercise vividly.

I was assigned team captain
and given a bright orange vest
to cement my authority.

I had never managed anyone, much
less a team of MBAs learning
to manufacture circuit boards.

And I was instantly
over my head.

My saving grace was my
teammates, one of whom

had management experience
and could have easily taken

over, but instead
remained on the sidelines

and offered advice
and tough feedback,

and asked where he
could be most helpful.

Another stepped in
to run our Kaizen
while I resolved another issue.
I had the orange vest.

But in those moments, they
showed the true leadership.

From what I've
learned here at HBS,

leadership starts
with showing up.

And that doesn't mean showing
up when your boss's boss is
on the Zoom.

It's showing up when there's
no credit to be given
or points to be won.

Leadership is running towards
instead of away from a crisis,
and asking, what can I do?

It's finding a little
more bandwidth when

you think you've run out,
and following through
on your commitments.

Leadership understands
that our lives and careers

are in service to others,
and not to ourselves.

And what makes a difference,
ideally a positive one?

Identifying a problem
before it happens

and fixing it, even if it
means no one will know you did.

Taking a step back to see who
is thriving, who is struggling,
and who is going unnoticed.

Listening to an opinion
different than your own,
even when it makes you cringe.

Having the courage to say I
was wrong or I don't know.

Sometimes, it's understanding
that life is not fair,

but maintaining a capacity
for hope and lighting the way

for others, even when
you cannot see ahead.

Over the last year, we have
experienced a world on fire.

I have seen acts that
were meant to hurt,

to undermine, to exclude, to
seek credit where none is due.

But I have also seen
true leadership,

through thousands of little
decisions from members
of this class.

And I ask that you continue
to be leaders in ways
that inspire the rest of us.

To finish this MBA
and become leaders

who make a difference
in the world,

we must first
recognize that our role

is to create
opportunity for others

to succeed, and to trust that
our small actions build up

to create movements
and change lives.

Class of 2021, we have
known loss and uncertainty
like few classes before us.

But today, let's commit
ourselves to turn away
from fear and towards hope.
The world is waiting.
